context.p: When you add a kernel to Walrus, you bundle the kernel file, upload the file to a bucket in Walrus that you name, and then register the kernel with Eucalyptus.
To add a kernel to Walrus:

example.codeblock:
euca-bundle-image -i euca-fedora-10-x86_64/xen-kernel/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen --kernel true ... Generating manifest /tmp/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml
euca-upload-bundle -b example_kernel_bucket -m /tmp/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml ... Uploaded image as example_kernel_bucket/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml
euca-register example_kernel_bucket/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml IMAGE eki-XXXXXXXX
example.p: Where the returned value eki-XXXXXXXX is the unique ID of the registered kernel image.
